title: This will make you a better decision maker | Annie Duke (Thinking In Bets, former pro poker player)
key_insights: Discover opinions independently before group discussions to avoid conformity bias and groupthink
Make implicit decision-making criteria explicit to improve decision quality and enable feedback loops
There are no truly long feedback loops - you can choose to shorten them by tracking leading indicators
Pre-mortems are only effective when paired with pre-committed kill criteria and specific actions
Alignment is unrealistic - focus on having people feel heard rather than achieving agreement
By the time you're thinking about quitting, you've likely already waited too long
Structure meetings for discussion only - discovery and decision-making should happen separately
Mental time travel helps provide perspective on current problems and their long-term significance

guest_background.current_role: Special Partner at First Round Capital, Decision-making consultant

topics_discussed: Daniel Kahneman's influence and lessons on humility and curiosity
Independent opinion gathering vs group brainstorming
Shortening feedback loops in venture capital investing
First Round Capital's structured decision-making process
Pre-mortems and kill criteria for product development
Parenting frameworks and decision-making with children
The psychology of quitting and sunk cost fallacy
Stewart Butterfield's decision to shut down Glitch and create Slack
Making implicit knowledge explicit in hiring and evaluation
The problems with seeking alignment in team decisions
Mental time travel as a decision-making tool
Nominal group techniques for better collaboration
memorable_quotes: There is no such thing as a long feedback loop. You can make a decision about how long the feedback loop is.
It's so incredibly necessary in improving decision quality to take what's implicit and make it explicit.
Nothing is as important as it seems when you're thinking about it.
summary: Annie Duke shares actionable frameworks for better decision-making, including how to structure meetings, shorten feedback loops, and make implicit judgments explicit. The conversation covers practical applications from parenting to venture capital, with a focus on overcoming cognitive biases through structured processes.
